abstract: General Motors‘ plan for a turnaround may not be enough to save the automaker from eventually falling into official bankruptcy, since it needs its bondholders to approve the plan. That is likely to be a very tall order, since bondholders have rejected G.M’s current proposal.
snippet: General Motors‘ plan for a turnaround may not be enough to save the automaker from eventually falling into official bankruptcy, since it needs its bondholders to approve the plan. That is likely to be a very tall order, since bondholders have reje...
lead_paragraph: Update | 5:46 p.m. The turnaround plan offered Monday by General Motors may not be enough to save the automaker from falling into bankruptcy. Even if G.M. does receive enough federal money to stay afloat, the company also needs its bondholders to approve any turnaround plan. That is likely to be a very tall order.

headline.main: G.M. Faces Obstacle From Unsecured Creditors
